SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuing my remarks on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill, I want to direct most of my comments to the attitude of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and the Hawke socialist Government, their disposition towards social welfare in this country. I particularly want to make reference to the attitude of the Minister and to the disgraceful amnesty that this Bill enshrines. During his political career the Minister for Social Security has endeavoured to teach the people of Australia about class-class distinctions and class privileges. During the Fraser years he was convinced, and no doubt is still convinced, that the conservative political parties in Australia were hell-bent on grinding the poor into the ground. This is not the case. Let me assure the House and the people of this nation that the Liberal and National parties in coalition government have a fine record of initiating, instituting and supporting measures for the poor, the needy, the disabled, the aged and veterans.
—We have been leaders.

—Yes, we have been leaders, as the honourable member for Hume reminds me. In his crusade against democracy, the Minister made some very silly accusations indeed. We have had to put up with statements such as this from the broad Left conference on 28 March this year, when the Minister for Social Security said:

SPEECH.PARA: Fraser and Howard believe government support made the poor lazy while the rich needed government support through incentives provided by tax breaks and subsidies.
Again, from that broad Left conference:
Our institutional structures, both public and private, are largely geared to suit the needs of wealth and privilege.

I suspect that the Minister fancies himself as a modern day Robin Hood-little Red Robbing Hood. His purpose in life is to steal from the rich and give to the poor-a philosophy for others, but obviously not for the Minister for Social Security himself. I wish he were in the House. He ought to be in the House to carry this legislation. Like a lot of Government members, he has not got much time or sympathy for the people in between. As M. A. Jones wrote in 1977 in the work Australian Society:

. . . in the group immediately above the poverty population who are in the workforce and often pay substantial amounts of tax, especially indirect tax, and work hard at unattractive jobs at incomes very similar to those received by the welfare class. This group are often understandably hostile to an expression of welfare benefits, especially to the so-called undeserving poor.

I would like to indulge for a short time in reflection of the Minister's performance during the early 1980s when debate in this House centred around taxation laws affecting evasion and avoidance. I am very pleased that the Minister for Social Security has seen fit to come into the chamber. This is appropriate because a significant function of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill is to provide for the Hawke socialist Government's weak attempt to curb welfare fraud. Tax evasion, that is, denying governments revenue, is no different from welfare fraud, which also denies governments revenue. On 22 April 1982, speaking on the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill, the Minister for Social Security accused the then Fraser Government of `lacking determination to get to the root of tax avoidance issues'. He said that the Fraser Government did not appear to be threatening to take, or taking a strong position against tax fraud. He was talking, he said, about cases in which millions of dollars-perhaps tens of millions of dollars-could be lost in terms of taxation. They were the words of the Minister for Social Security. Figures describing the extent of social security fraud today range from $20m to $1 billion annually. In August of 1982 the Minister responsible for this present legislation advised the Fraser Government:

It ought to be suggesting that where people are not prepared to conform to what we regard as good practice in terms of Australian interests, where they are attempting to get around our taxation laws, avoid our taxation laws, they ought to recognise and they ought to know that a very serious risk is involved.

A year earlier, in 1981, he had the audacity to say that the Fraser Government had failed to stop tax avoidance effectively, because that Government was not serious about it. The reason he gave was that the then Treasurer, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), had `too may friends who were into it'. We find that in the Hansard record at page 135 on 25 February 1981. `It' was tax evasion. It begs the question: Who are the Minister's friends? Are they into social welfare fraud?

There is a significant trend in this country to scorn anyone who suggests that we dob in our mates. When the shadow Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), suggested that the Government institute an Operation Noah-style campaign against social security cheats, he met with scathing criticism. The Labor Government, which I might add is occasionally controlled by a man who is a contrived embodiment of all that is Australian, said that such a measure would be downright un-Australian. Operation Noah was hailed as a successful attempt at gathering information from the public about drug traffic suspects. However, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) just would not stand for a dob-in on those who cheat the social security system. You just cannot tell on your mates, even if behind your back they are doing you an injustice. The rhetoric members of the Government use is fascinating stuff. The Government's muted-some might say dumb-attack on welfare fraud through amnesty only applies, to quote the Minister again:
. . . to people who've omitted to do something-that is, they failed to advise a change of financial or other circumstances. It has been specifically designed for people on the treadmill.

Let me examine what the word `treadmill' means. My paperback Oxford Dictionary says that it is a wide mill turned by the weight of people treading on steps fixed around its edge and which, formerly, was worked by prisoners as a punishment. The Minister, at the table, might well smile. I cannot imagine that the Hawke socialist Government is suggesting that welfare recipients are on the treadmill as some sort of punishment. On the other hand, `treadmill' can mean tiring, monotonous, routine work. That does not apply too well, either, because a lot of social security beneficiaries do not actually work, unless they are claiming the dole and working as well and somehow omit to tell the Department of Social Security that they have a job. One wonders how that could happen.

So who are these people caught on the treadmill? According to the Minister's news releases, some of them are newcomers to Australia. Such newcomers apparently have been in the country for only a very short time and have not had time to learn the welfare system ropes. Nonetheless, according to the Government, they have been here long enough to get on the treadmill. I can assure the Minister for Social Security that when I was Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs many people who arrived here with little or no English as first arrivals seemed to know more about our social welfare system than many people who had been here half their lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with that.

—The Minister says that he agrees with that. Before the angels of mercy on the benches opposite accuse me of considering people on welfare as lazy and stupid, I believe that genuine recipients deserve all the help they can get. Indeed, many deserve more. But I know that a welfare state can never satisfy its dependants. The Minister for Social Security has admitted:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . mere incrementalism-giving a dollar here and there-on its own is neither effective or affordable.

He made that comment to a civilian widows' convention on 7 March this year. But that is what social security in this country is all about-giving a dollar here and there, only just keeping up with the cost of living. If the Minister heeded his Treasurer perhaps he could accept that this country does not have the resources to be turned into a total welfare state. He ought to know, as every other taxpayer and resident in this country knows, that there is no bottomless pit of funds. He would know that the Treasurer sees an urgent need to reduce Australia's massive deficit. But the Minister believes that worrying about deficits is nonsense. He is ashamed that his Government's outlays rate so poorly compared to those of other countries. `Deficit fetishism' he calls it. Is that correct, Minister? He nods approval. There will never be enough funds in Australia to rescue the poor securely from poverty. The coalition knows it and the economic pragmatists in the Hawke socialist Government know it, not that they are doing much about it.
I return to the illusive treadmill. I ask the Minister a question in view of his statement on 17 April this year in which he stated:
The limited amnesty on social security payments was making a significant contribution to the overall campaign against fraud and overpayments.

How many social security recipients on the treadmill have already reported that they have been in receipt of over payments and how much has been saved as a result since the amnesty's inception? As the amnesty came into force in February and will finish at the end of May - the Minister was able to reassure us that it was working significantly well by 17 April - that is a question he must surely be able to answer. My next question to the Minister is: If one were not quick enough to jump off the treadmill this time, when will the next opportunity arise which will allow one to do so? The Minister shakes his head. It does not look as though it is going to happen. There is an amnesty now, so why not another amnesty in the future?

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you advocating that?

—No, I am not advocating it. I would never have had an amnesty in the first place. Why cease the amnesty at all? Why not continue it right through? This legislation is a disgrace. Surely people know whether they are entitled to a benefit. After all, the Government spends enough money on propaganda telling people about what is up for grabs. The tone of the amnesty is not threatening. It does not even appear to be threatening. In fact, one could say that the people this Government requests to come forward under the amnesty are being treated as the victims of some complex and nightmarish administrative system. The two social security offices in my electorate in the south east corner of Queensland, and including Brisbane central office, are in good shape. I believe that the departmental officers are caring and helpful to people.

SPEECH.PARA: This is weak legislation. The Government is apologising to beneficiaries who know that they are receiving overpayments and that they are breaking the law. The Minister for Social Security passionately believes that Australians do not give a damn about the welfare class. He believes that our public and private structures pander to the needs of wealth and privilege. Let me quote to the House what Professor David Kemp said recently in a speech, because it is well put. He said:

Australians as a people possibly place a higher value on helping those in genuine need than any other nation. Not only does Government provide 80 per cent of the income of one-fifth of Australian households: There is also an enormous private welfare effort in Australia which goes largely unnoticed. A 1984 report from the Social Welfare Research Centre in New South Wales discovered some 25,000 or more non-government welfare organisations in Australia attracting some $1.5 to $3 billion from private sources. These organisations employ several hundred thousand people and in addition enlist the aid of possibly as many as 1.7 million volunteers. Australians are not lacking concern for the unfortunate.

Welfare reproduces poverty and the social security system does not rouse people to succeed. This Bill is yet another excuse for them to rely on that system. It is another example of reproducing poverty. Through this Bill the Hawke Government will extend financial assistance to genuinely homeless youth. They will welcome the new benefit. But thanks to this budgetary measure parents prone to neglect their children have no reason to give them a second thought. That is one of the failings of this measure.

The one law Australia needs and has not got is one whereby when people decide to embark on the adventure and pleasures of child creation they undertake to be responsible for the product of that adventure. We have now an Act on affirmative action, an Act on sex discrimination and a Bill to implement an amnesty for welfare cheats, and still nothing has been done to prevent blatant abuse of court orders for child maintenance. Some 40 per cent of all such orders are ignored, according to the Institute of Family Studies. I hope the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is responsible in this total area of welfare nationally, will take note of that and I hope that he will make some comment about it. Another 20 per cent of such orders are paid only sporadically.

This amnesty, this impotent response to social security fraud, stings everyone, ordinary taxpayers and genuine welfare recipients alike-everyone except of course the welfare cheats. The Hawke Government has its thick head in the clouds if it seriously thinks that most people in receipt of overpayments receive them innocently. That is what this Minister is saying. The Hawke socialist Government has its thick head in the clouds if it seriously believes that the amnesty has adequate provisions for distinguishing innocent fraud from premeditated fraud. What measures are there to determine whether the Department is actually being told the truth by those people who do come forward and admit that they have been accidentally trapped on the treadmill? Welfare fraud in Australia is extensive; the Hawke Government has failed all honest citizens by choosing to take the soft approach to it. It is just another soft option that is always taken by Prime Minister Hawke. He has never taken a hard decision or hard option in his life. A dollar into one person's pocket is a dollar out of someone else's. The average Australian taxpayer, the person situated just above the welfare belt, is fed up with footing the bill for cheats and scoundrels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Social Security Legislation Bill 1986. This is a very comprehensive piece of legislation which will correct many anomalies and minor technical drafting defects in the principal Act and will provide a legislative basis for several important measures introduced by the Government. I shall not attempt to canvass all the amendments, but confine my remarks to some of the major points of the legislation. The remarks of the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) were not at all illuminative. The honourable member is a former Minister, a shining example of why his Party is now in Opposition and why it will stay there. He says that the Hawke Government has its head in the clouds. I would respectfully suggest that it is better than being a conservative who has his head in the sand.

SPEECH.PARA: The highlight of this legislation is the introduction from 1 July this year of the young homeless allowance for homeless and unsupported young-people of 16 and 17 years of age. This allowance was foreshadowed in the 1985-86 Budget Paper No. 13 on youth policies. The young homeless allowance which will be equivalent to the tertiary education allowance of $73.28 per week is available only under very strict conditions to ensure that there is no incentive for young people to leave home. I applaud the Government's action towards these unfortunate youngsters. I am appalled at the obvious breakdown in our society which has resulted in so many of our young people having to leave their homes because of intolerable conditions. It is a sad commentary on our society that there are some parents who can turn their backs on their children and leave them to face the world alone.

I know all honourable members here would share my horror at the numerous Press reports which appear in all papers, almost on a daily basis, about young children, even as young as seven years, who are homeless and have no means of support. I find these reports so very depressing. I am reminded of the quotation which appeared at the front of that excellent Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare report on homeless youth which said:

Homeless youths' needs are hardly extravagant and certainly fall within the inalienable rights of all people: the right to food, shelter and a positive and loving family environment. Since homeless youngsters do not have these needs fulfilled in a family context, it may be necessary to explore independent living facilities, teach them life skills and give them support for an interim period while they move toward adulthood.

I draw honourable members' attention to the recommendations contained in chapter 5 of that report, and I am so very pleased that this Government has recognised the need of these youngsters who are homeless and without support. It is a tragedy that we find so many youngsters living in all manner of unsatisfactory circumstances-in refuges, in substandard group housing, even in parks and bus shelters, open to all kinds of exploitation and dangers.

The Government's swift action to implement the young homeless allowance from 1 July this year shows its determination to ensure that young unsupported people, in genuine need, are provided with adequate and equitable support, in line with the Priority One program. It is estimated that the homeless youth allowance will involve an expenditure of $2m over 1986-87 and $2m in 1987-88. The introduction of the homeless youth allowance and the amendment to `bar' unemployment or sickness benefits or special benefits to full-time students who are eligible to education allowances is a related issue. This latter amendment has arisen as a result of recent Administrative Appeals Tribunal decisions for the payment of special benefits to unsupported school students.

The Government is anxious that full time students should be covered by education allowances rather than what are primarily work-related benefits. Since a corresponding young homeless allowance will be available separately under the secondary assistance scheme program, full time students will be more appropriately assisted by education allowances, and the Government has made provision to ensure that those students currently receiving special benefits will receive those benefits until the end of the academic year. As a result of this bar amendment, it is estimated that savings will be in the order of $410m in 1986-87 and $20m in 1987-88. Many young people whose educational opportunities have been severely limited through a lack of parental support will now be able to pursue their studies at both secondary and tertiary levels. This Government has again demonstrated its awareness of the problems facing so many of our young people today, and I am so very proud of the Hawke Labor Government's record in implementing policies designed to alleviate poverty and difficult circumstances confronting these youngsters. This Government has made young Australians our number one priority.

I turn now to another important aspect in this legislation. This Bill provides the legislative basis for the Government's social security amnesty announced on 12 February this year which runs till 31 May. As all honourable members are aware, the amnesty applies only to those people who are, or at least were at one stage, genuine clients of the Department of Social Security who failed to notify a change in circumstances that would have reduced their level of payment. Those people voluntarily coming forward during the amnesty could do so without any fear of a penalty or liability to repay any overpayment.

The amnesty arose from the need to reduce the massive social security overpayments, but did not cover those people deliberately defrauding the system, and the Opposition misunderstands that position. At a time when the Government is faced with the massive task of providing benefits to so many of the needy in our society, as a result of the amnesty there will be a substantial reduction in overpayments. The Government has introduced an essential integrated strategy designed to prevent future overpayments and has improved the means of identifying and investigating fraud and overpayments. By harnessing many recent technological advances, implementing a range of administrative reforms, removing legal ambiguities in the Social Security Act, and committing additional resources to this task, the Government intends to reduce the level of social security overpayments over the next three years. Savings to the Australian taxpayers are expected to be in the order of $90m by 1988.

The Government's strategy is based on one fundamental precept: That there is no one, simplistic solution to the problem of social security overpayment. The Government recognises that, if overpayments are to be tackled effectively, there must be a comprehensive strategy in place which integrates a wide range of measures, covering all aspects to do with the prevention, detection, calculation and recovery of over- payments. Reducing poverty is too important a goal for the Government to tolerate fraud in the social security system. I understand that the toll-free hotline set up during the amnesty has been most successful and that a large number of genuine `treadmill' people have taken advantage of the amnesty to set the record straight.

The Bill before us also contains new arrangements for the treatment of a lump sum amount of compensation received by a sickness beneficiary, with effect from 1 July this year. I am sure all honourable members have been approached by constituents who have been confused about compensation claims and sickness benefits. At present the Act guards against double dipping by providing sickness benefits to be reduced, not paid, or recovered, where compensation covers the same period. However, there is uncertainty about the treatment of lump sums. The new arrangements will require a lump sum payable as from 1 July 1986 to be regarded as a series of periodical payments equal to average weekly earnings, thus providing a precise period of preclusion from sickness benefit, or a precise period in which sickness benefit is recoverable. The new arrangements are expected to create savings of $20m in 1986-87 and $20m in 1987-88.

This legislation also provides for the abolition as from 1 July 1986 of an anomaly by which the rate of unemployment beneficiaries who are legally married but permanently separated is higher than for an unmarried person. This is a much fairer arrangement, and is likely to create savings in the vicinity of $4.5m in 1986-87 and $5m in 1987-88. It is important to stress that, whilst this Bill will generate considerable savings in some areas, the Government has maintained its commitment to provide for the most needy in our society.

In looking at this Labor Government's achievements, it is important to remember the entrenched poverty we inherited from the previous coalition Government, which presented a major challenge for the Government. Let me give the House a few examples of allowances which had fallen in real terms under the previous Government. The additional pension for children had declined by 34.7 per cent; the mothers/guardians allowance had declined by the same amount; rent assistance had dropped by 2.1 per cent; the single adult unemployment benefit had declined by 18.6 per cent; and the junior unemployment benefit had collapsed by 45.6 per cent.

Indexation of the single adult unemployment benefit rate was withdrawn in 1978 and had fallen nearly $13 behind the single adult pension rate by 1983. Indexation of other pensions and benefits was changed from six-monthly to annually and reversed only after vigorous community protest. Poverty deepened through the 1982-83 Howard recession, as the numbers on unemployment benefit increased. For instance, in 1980 there were 311,232 people on unemployment benefits. In 1981 there were 314,500. In 1982 there were 390,664, and in 1983 there were 635,000-nearly double the figure for 1980. However, in 1984 this figure had decreased to 584,000, and there was a further drop in 1985 to 561,000.

Under the previous Government's economic strategy the unemployed were made to bear the burden of economic change. Under that Government ever increasing levels of unemployment became an accepted fact of life and increasing numbers of Australia's youth faced permanent exclusion from a normal economic and social life. But this Government recognised that the record levels of unemployment it inherited were a major cause of poverty. It has created over 600,000 new jobs through successful economic management policies.

In its social security programs, this Government has: Increased payments to those in greatest need; eased the transition from welfare to work through an attack on poverty traps; improved access to social security programs for disadvantaged groups such as migrants; introduced a common youth allowance to improve income support provisions for young people; and redirected expenditure to free resources for people in poverty. A number of other positive benefits have accrued to the Australian people.

I would like to refer to many more of the positive features of this legislation which is being brought forward by this Government, but time has beaten me. I conclude by saying that I am very proud of the Government's record and particularly proud of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is making a tremendous effort to help the most disadvantaged members of our society. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that I, along with all other members on this side of the House, should feel sorry for the people of Australia who have had to listen to the diatribe from the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon). He mentioned-and I understand that there has been no chopping of the time available to individual speakers in this debate-that he had run out of time. Well, he still had another seven or eight minutes left and I suggest respectfully that he simply ran out of things to say. He was trying to suggest that the previous Government, the Fraser-Anthony Government, had a very poor record in the area of social security. My colleague the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) has shown that that is simply not the case. If one could believe the words of the honourable member for Hunter, the more spent in the area of social welfare the better it is for the country. We know that that statement is simply not correct. We should look at how the money is spent. We should ensure that it is getting to those people in need and those people who are deserving of the receipt of social welfare payments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 which is before us today seeks to make a number of amendments to the Social Security Act and the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971. The nature of the legislation, and the amnesty provided for, gives honourable members the opportunity to talk about this Government's approach to social welfare and its effect on the Australian economy. The Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) in his second reading speech outlined that amendments to the Social Security Act also included the introduction of the young homeless allowance; a bar to payment of unemployment, sickness or special benefit to a full time student who is eligible, in principle, for an education allowance; a change in the treatment of lump sum compensation payable to sickness beneficiaries; and a change in the rate of benefit that applies to a legally married but permanently separated unemployment beneficiary to the rate that applies to a single unemployment beneficiary.

The Minister has claimed-and I am pleased to see that he is in the chamber to listen to what I have to say this morning-that the changes to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act will improve the administration of the compensation system. We in the National Party of Australia, and indeed our coalition partners, would say that any improvement in the maladministration by this Government is a step in the right direction. We should consider that many people come forward and say that this or that payment, or this or that benefit, is necessary to assist certain groups in the community. I am certain that every member of this House would like to assist, more than we as a nation are economically able, those people who are in need. However, this nation has finite resources and the Hawke Government is sending Australia down the financial chute in the same direction as Argentina. I digress to recommend that people should read a book by Duncan and Fogarty entitled Australia and Argentina on Parallel Paths, published by the Melbourne University Press in 1984. The comparisons are frightening and horrifying. I wonder what sort of society we will hand over to our children in years to come. What we must do is look at the resources we have available. We must use those resources in the best possible manner to make sure that that money gets through to those people who are in need of help.

Unfortunately, the Government's approach in this Bill once again fails to address the key issues of high government expenditure, the blowout in expenditure on social welfare, and the development of a handout mentality on the part of a growing number of Australian citizens. In The Other America, Harrington stated:
There is the fundamental paradox of the welfare state; that it is not built for the desperate, but for those who are already capable of helping themselves.

I do not agree entirely with what Mr Harrington said. However, I do suggest that we must make sure that in fact money and assistance get through to the needy and not to the greedy. In his second reading speech the Minister had the audacity to say that the youth policies in the 1985-86 Budget recognised the need to support young people, whether students or unemployed. Young people are Australia's future and we in the National Party and the Liberal Party would very strongly support this principle. However, the simple fact of the matter is that Labor's sad record shows that it has little or no concern for the youth of Australia. The damning figures speak clearly for themselves.

In the period since the ill-fated 1983 election of the Hawke Labor Government, Labor has seen the recipients of unemployment benefit grow from 5.7 per cent of the labour force to 7.76 per cent of the labour force. So much for the party which has full unemployment as a tenet! What a joke! It is even worse if we look at the situation for those people who are aged from 18 years to 24 years, because the figures show that almost 40 per cent of those people are jobless. I suggest that unless something is done as a matter of extreme urgency over these figures Government members will join the jobless queue after the next election.

The Government has no right to claim to be helping those people studying in Australia. Last year during debate in this House honourable members would have clearly heard of the numbers of students being refused access to our tertiary institutions. Under current Labor education funding many thousands have suffered in this way. I am quite certain that every member of the House of Representatives would have had constituents come to him or her complaining over the fact that students are not able to gain places in higher education institutes and universities.

If we believe the Federal Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, 10,000 people have been denied places. Perhaps it was at the massive level of 30,000 which was suggested by the shadow Minister for Education, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), last year. I might add that the honourable member for Tangney's figures are likely to be more realistic. In any event it is common ground that thousands upon thousands of young Australians cannot gain places in tertiary institutions. Labor is cheating these young people of their futures and it is indeed a sad and sorry state of affairs when more and more have no alternative but to join Labor's dole queues. The warning lights are flashing and the Government must realise that its economic policies are directly contributing to the desperate plight of youth in this country.

In this Bill we now see the introduction of a new allowance for 16- and 17-year-olds who are homeless and without support. While I do not dispute that assistance should be given to those in genuine need whose families have rejected them, I sincerely hope that this new allowance will not encourage young people to leave home and will not encourage the continued breakup of the family unit, which we in the National Party believe is the fundamental unit in our society. However, I do believe that the current Government's approach to social welfare is rapidly fostering the idea that many people expect that the Government should look after them from the cradle to the grave. I am sure that such a mentality could not have been thought of in the 1898 Federal Convention which decided that the provision of age and invalid pensions should be a Federal function.

When the first social security policies were being considered in the late 1890s, there were basically three modest objectives: Firstly, to supplement relief provided by families and voluntary charitable institutions to the deserving aged and poor people so as to ensure them a basic minimum level of well-being; secondly, to provide this assistance in a way which would not discourage thrift and self-reliance; and, finally, to limit expenditure on such relief to a fair and reasonable amount for the community to provide. Unfortunately, it would seem today that this policy direction is being thrown by the wayside. We on this side of the House support assistance for those people who need assistance. What we do oppose is the sort of profligate expenditure which the Government seems to have in so many areas. Perhaps the Government feels bound to bring in some of these things to satisfy the ideological concerns of a colleague opposite, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand). I do not know. It is a sad state of affairs that the honourable member for Melbourne seems to exert and exercise ever greater control over the policies of this Government.

We have to look at what is desirable and we have to compare that with what is affordable. We must assist the genuine and we must try, as the honourable member for Richmond pointed out, to stamp out fraud. The Government is bringing in an amnesty sham. That was covered very successfully and effectively in his usual manner by my parliamentary neighbour and colleague, the honourable member for Petrie. We should look at what the Government is not doing in some of the fraudulent cases which have arisen because of the way in which the Government has not kept a sufficiently tight control on social security matters. We should look at some of the headlines of articles in the various newspapers, such as: `Inquiry called on prisoners' dole', `Dole cheque leaves taxi industry short on drivers', a headline in the Advertiser of July last year; a headline in the Courier-Mail, `Dole fraud case: Second man charged'; a headline in the West Australian, `Victorian racket on pensions suspected'; the West Australian again, `Police tell of big-time welfare rackets'. The headlines go on: Where does it all end? Other headlines state: `Fraud in welfare system', `Crime cheats hit welfare', and so on until we get this gem which was published a couple of years ago: `Four drew $17,000 a week dole, court told'.

The Government is going to misrepresent, as it always tends to do, people on this side of the chamber by suggesting that we are not concerned about the interests of those people who need government assistance, those people who in a humane society need the backing of government because they are not able to fend for themselves. I am certain that the men and women of Australia, the people of this country, will reject absolutely, as they quite often do, the claims by the Government that the Opposition is not sincere, that it does not have the interests of the people of Australia at heart. While I do not dispute that there are lots and lots of people in need of social security benefits-the record of the Fraser-Anthony Government stands for itself, it is an excellent record and I commend it-I believe that the current ballooning of expenditure and fraud is fast reaching plague proportions.

There are already signs throughout the country that people have had enough. The current situation does absolutely nothing to encourage thrift and self-reliance, and is fast approaching a limit that is unfair and unreasonable for the community to continue to provide, not to say unaffordable. Something positive must be done to reverse this situation, and I commend the Government to adopt the Opposition's attitudes in this area. One thing that we should look at is the dole and the way in which the dole is paid to unemployed people. I would very strongly support the principle of work value or education courses before people are eligible for the dole.

The community's concern at the growing social security crisis could be no more clearly illustrated than by Press reports during April in Queensland calling for a re-examination of the supporting parent's benefit. The support for the Queensland Minister for Welfare Services, Mrs Yvonne Chapman, over this issue interestingly enough has been overwhelming. The facts of this matter are quite simple: Payouts under the supporting parent's benefit cost the taxpayers $25.2m per week, and some 168,000 single parents receive this benefit annually at a cost, I understand, coming up next year of something like $1,200m. Can we afford this expenditure? The cost to the Australian taxpayer for this benefit has mushroomed by well over 600 per cent in the past 10 years. In Queensland alone the cost in 1984-85 was nearly $200m, and the points raised by Mrs Chapman are extremely pertinent.

There are indeed quite a number of unmarried mothers who are now receiving supporting parent's benefits to which they have no legal right. No one knows the exact number of women in this category. Of course, many women who receive the supporting parent benefit are entitled to it under the present guidelines. But, unfortunately, the system is once again being ripped off. I wish to draw to the attention of the House an article in the Canberra Times of 11 December 1985 under the headline `Nine-month confinement follows bogus baby case'. It refers to a case of a 38-year-old woman, a mother of six children, who was sentenced to six months gaol for a $60,000 social security fraud. The magistrate, referring to this lady, is reported as follows:
`This lady has worked the system beautifully and I find it very difficult not to gaol her'. He said she had displayed `calculated deception'.

An officer for the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions told the court that in addition to claiming for her own six children the defendant had invented three other children and claimed in her sister's name as well as her own for a family allowance and supporting parent benefit for up to 14 years. She claimed under three names-her own, that of her sister Christine, and under her de facto married name. Her reply was:
I've just been plain stupid and thought I would not get caught.

Those are the sorts of matters that should be picked up and investigated by this Government. How many such cases have not yet come to light? Following the announcement of her statement regarding welfare payments to unmarried mothers, Mrs Chapman's office was contacted by numerous people who provided the names of single mothers living fraudulently on taxpayers' money. Since she made the initial comments Mrs Chapman has received over 5,000 telephone calls. Fewer than 20 people have contacted her to complain about her statement. The Minister for Social Security quite wrongly accused Mrs Chapman on 10 April of pushing reactionary and conservative attitudes. But the people of Australia, the people of Queensland, and the people of the State electorate of Pine Rivers in Queensland reject absolutely the false assertions of the Minister for Social Security in this area. We do not oppose assistance going to people who are entitled to it. But I repeat that we are opposed to the present open cheque book mentality of this Government.

The Courier-Mail in Brisbane ran a special phone-in line regarding Mrs Chapman's comments. Eighty per cent of those who contacted the newspaper supported her. The comments reported in the newspaper are quite clear. One was:
Good on you Mrs Chapman. It is about time someone called white white and black black. I am on your side.
Another was:

Each individual in this country has the right to live as he or she chooses. However, every action is followed by a consequence, and usually a responsibility. I believe that if a single woman has a baby, that is strictly between herself and the father of her child. The responsibility for the financial support of that child should not fall upon any taxpayer.

Mrs Chapman did not say that women should not get the supporting parent benefit for the first child. What she said was that, after a moratorium of 12 months, the supporting parent benefit benefit should not be paid for a second or subsequent child. Mrs Chapman's views do not affect deserted or divorced wives. What she said, and indeed what the Government is now belatedly saying, is that the parents and the fathers of those children should be pursued to obtain the necessary payments so that the cost and the burden does not continue to fall upon the Australian taxpayer. It is important to note that the Government is now moving in this area. For once I find myself in agreement with the Minister. I would like to compliment him for trying to make sure that in future people who bring children into the world are responsible for their upkeep.

I also want to talk about the situation regarding work value for the dole. This should not be considered as being in opposition to young people. If we had work value, we would encourage those who do not want to work to get off the dole. If they have to work for the dole, they might as well get a job with higher pay which would be the case from paid employment. Work value would also help those who want to work. It would help them to keep and improve their work skills and would restore self-respect and dignity. I have spoken to unemployed people, older people and people at community youth support schemes. I have yet to find someone opposed to this idea. The community would benefit because the work value would go into sporting clubs and service organisations in the same way as the community service alternative helps people in Queensland who are not able to pay fines.
A humane society will always give a fair go to people in need. We need a fair social welfare system in Australia and we on this side of the House will continue to strive for it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the previous Government's record-the record of these men and women of compassion, these people who have decided that they have suddenly discovered poverty and hardship within our society. The honourable member for Maranoa has just entered the chamber, just returned from his radio interview in which he said some of the most outrageous things about women and children in situations in which they find themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was only telling you blokes a few home truths.

—If he will just be quiet, he might learn something. Opposition members are now claiming to be compassionate towards poor people. We heard them talk on the adjournment last night about the poor. But I will tell honourable members what the previous Government did for the poor. There was a fall in real terms of 34.7 per cent in the additional pension for children when the previous Government was in office. The mother's and guardian's allowance fell by 34.7 per cent. Rent assistance fell by 2.1 per cent. The adult unemployment benefit rate fell by 18.6 per cent. The junior unemployment benefit rate fell by 45.6 per cent when the Liberal-National Party Government was in office. Those people now pretend to care about the poor.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened to the numbers of unemployed? In 1980, 311,000 people were unemployed in this country. When the previous Government went out of office that figure had doubled.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's gone up 200,000 since April.
—The previous Government created a crisis in this community unheard of and unseen before. The former Government created no new employment.
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Melbourne will be heard in silence.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. He is not talking to someone he thinks he can stand over in this place as he was this morning. If we want to talk about rip-off merchants, for God's sake, let us have a look at what went on under the previous Government. We are justified in giving assistance to the poor and to those people who find themselves in hard times due to climatic conditions. I support all that. But for God's sake, the Opposition is suggesting that we should tip $6 billion to $8 billion into the rural industry with no trouble at all. We are one-upping one another all the time. Members of the Liberal Party of Australia offer a 10-point package and out comes the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) and he offers an 11-point package. Away they go. The Opposition has no trouble offering $6 billion to $8 billion assistance to the rural industry. It will not allow those people to get out of the rut that they are in. It is about condemning and reinforcing the class situation in this country. `Keep them poor, keep them ignorant but look after our mates and rip-off the system' is what this Opposition is really about. The honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) stood up in this chamber showing us headline after headline and reading quote after quote but what good does that do for the kids such as those who were out on the front steps of Parliament House yesterday? Honourable members opposite have helped to create this society because they are older than those kids I have mentioned. TALK.START.PARA: —There were 700,000 yesterday.

—I never said that at all. Read the Hansard when it comes out, you fool, and you will understand. The honourable member should get back to his book. —We are trying to do something about it and I will come to that now. The Fraser-Howard Government was in office in the period 1976 to 1983. Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish I could get some protection from the Chair from this imbecile.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I really object to the honourable member for Melbourne referring to the honourable member for Maranoa as an imbecile and I ask you for a withdrawal of the remark.
—The honourable member for Melbourne will withdraw.

—Is the word `imbecile' offensive? If it is, I will withdraw it; but, Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your protection and I ask people not to annoy you so that I can be protected. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) is 18 inches taller than me and somewhat threatening.

—It is better than calling them spokesmen which is what the honourable member normally does. He forgets his colleague. I try to respect her presence in the chamber. Spokesperson after spokesperson in the Opposition has launched attack after attack on the unemployed, the single mums and the kids. Anybody in receipt of benefits has come under criticism. Yesterday a Queensland member, the honourable member for McPherson, called for the abolition of dole payments to under 18-year-olds. That is one example. Then we had the honourable member for Deakin--
—The beacon from Deakin.

—I know that the honourable member gets a bit of a glow up at times but I did not know it was the beacon. The honourable member proposes a savage cut in Federal spending, the abolition of first child family allowances-I am saying this slowly so that it can be recorded and sent to everybody in the honourable member's electorate-the elimination of public housing grants, tightened eligibility for unemployment benefits, and the list goes on. Those are the honourable member's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess this is best summed up by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) for whom one must have some sympathy. We had the wets and the dries and now we have the uglies in New South Wales. The uglies are a group of people who have been infiltrating the Liberal Party in New South Wales. They are led by some people who are described in newspaper cuttings and records as quizzlings from Yugoslavia. These people have taken over the Liberal Party in the Leader of the Opposition's State and they are inflicting their conservative views on the Leader of the Opposition. What has he got to do? He has to cut, cut, cut, and that is the sort of thing that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) does. Does the honourable member understand what I am saying? That is what he is suggesting. I am sure that the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) does not support the views of the uglies in New South Wales. Their attacks on the poor have become legendary. The Leader of the Opposition has no choice but to go along with the uglies. There are honourable members who know who those uglies are and what they represent; they have fought against them. They have fought against the principles those people express within branches of the Liberal Party. That is why we have this conservative thrust by the Opposition. The honourable member for Denison, the honourable member for Goldstein and other people who have some compassion-some have more than others-reject the uglies and the National Party of Australia line expressed by Heckle and Jeckle who sit opposite.
