Nevertheless, his sincerity cannot be doubted.

SPEECH.PARA: I will return to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill. It is a very large Bill covering many sections and no honourable member has been able to deal with any significant number of sections. Time for the debate is limited and along with other speakers I intend to confine myself to a specific area of the Bill. The area that has given the greatest public concern is the granting of amnesties to people who are receiving social security payments to which they are not entitled. I refer first of all to the specific information that is given in relation to the amnesty in the explanatory note tabled by the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) when he introduced this legislation. The explanatory note states:
Clause 45 (1) deals with the case of a person who fails to comply with an obligation under the Act to notify the occurrence of an event or a change in circumstances.
The note further states that as a result of this amendment:
. . . the person will not be guilty of a criminal offence under the Act and will not be liable to refund any overpayment made to the person.

An example of such a case is where a person claims a supporting parent's benefit and is properly granted that benefit, but the person subsequently marries or enters into a de facto relationship and fails to notify that fact.
Clause 45 (2) deals with the case of a person who makes a false statement (i.e. misrepresents the person's circumstances).

Where such a person subsequently voluntarily informs the Department of Social Security between 12 February 1986 and 31 May 1986, and the person is still in receipt of a social security payment, the person will not be guilty of a criminal offence under the Act and will not be liable to refund any overpayment. However, this will only be so where the misrepresentation was not deliberate, in cases where the misrepresentation resulted in the payment being made or the payment being made at a higher rate.
I contrast what is said in the memorandum with the speech the Minister made at the time he introduced the Bill and tabled that explanatory statement. The Minister stated:

The amnesty only applies to people who have omitted to do something-that is, they failed to advise a change of financial or other circumstances. It has been specifically designed for people on the `treadmill'.

I point out that the Bill does more than apply to people who have omitted to do something. The quote that I have just given from the explanatory note also deals with a person who makes a false statement, that is, misrepresents his or her circumstances. The Minister continued:

In effect, these people want to set the record straight, surrender the payment completely, or have the rate corrected downwards. However, they have been afraid to come forward in the past because they fear prosecution or having to repay the amount overpaid to them.

The amnesty allows these people to get off the `treadmill' without fear of repercussions. It is worth emphasising that the amnesty is for `treadmill' cases-not those deliberately cheating the system. The amnesty will have two main consequences.

I will come to them in a minute. There has been much emphasis by Government speakers about the social security recipients who are on the treadmill. From time to time one reads in the newspapers of cases where people have inadvertently received overpayments and the Department of Social Security is proceeding to recover them. On the basis of the stories one reads in the newspaper it would seem that sometimes there is a good case for not being too hard on the recipient. In other cases one sees that there is a very good case for being hard on the recipient.

When the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) spoke yesterday she made a statement that I found a little startling. Unfortunately, I do not have a copy of yesterday's Daily Hansard-I understand that it is not available yet-so I cannot look at her actual words and specifically quote her. However, I understood her to say at the time that all honourable members have had the experience of people who are on the treadmill coming into their office and saying: `Please help me. How do I get off?' As I recall, the honourable member for Phillip then went on to give an example of someone who had recently been to her office. That may be so but I can only honestly state that in the 12 years that I have been a member of parliament with large constituency work-I include when I was a senator-and notably very high female constituency work, I have never once had someone come to me and say: `I am receiving a pension payment which I fear I am not entitled to. Would you please give me some help in getting out from under what I think is looming ahead of me?' I am not saying that it does not happen. I am saying that it has never happened in my case. I have consulted a number of my colleagues who tell me that they have had the same experience as I have had. It may be that some members have had experience of a number of people coming to them in that position, and believe that it is therefore a widespread occurrence. However, if others were to judge on the basis of their experiences, they would say that it never happens. Thus, one cannot make the type of generalisation made by the honourable member for Phillip yesterday.

It will only be when the results of the amnesty are known that we will have any sort of quantification of the numbers of people who genuinely made a mistake in the information they originally gave in relation to their circumstances or who, because they had forgotten they had certain obligations, overlooked informing the Department of changes in their circumstances and therefore a change in their entitlement to the benefit they were receiving. I return to the Minister's second reading speech. He further stated:

The amnesty will have two main consequences. First, future outlays will be reduced because people who come forward between 12 February 1986 and 31 May 1986 under the amnesty will cease to receive payment or will be paid their correct entitlement in the future.
Second, correcting the record in these cases will allow resources to be better targeted on the prevention, detection and recovery of overpayments in deliberate fraud cases.

Without wishing to be overly cynical, there is a third benefit: Pressure is temporarily taken off the Department of Social Security-a pressure outlined in detail in the most recent Auditor-General's report, which is a damning indictment of the attitudes, procedures and attention to duty of sections of the Department of Social Security to its legal obligations under the Act to detect and pursue overpayment and fraud. I shall come to that in a minute, too.

At this stage I freely admit that the overpayments of social security are a problem to all governments, be they Liberal or Labor. In fact, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, when she was Minister, and Senator Fred Chaney, when he was Minister, were, I believe, vigorous in their attempts to find ways to prevent overpayment and fraud. Nevertheless, it happened and there were scandals from time to time in the term of the Fraser Government. There have been many Auditor-General's reports over the years, of both Liberal and Labor governments, which have been critical of administrative procedures in relation to detection and recovery of overpayments of social security and, indeed, in other types of overpayments. It is a problem that will always be with us, I suspect, human nature being what it is.

That does not mean that an amnesty is the answer. My personal suspicion is that the number of people who come forward under the amnesty and can prove genuineness will not be significant. In his second reading speech the Minister says that future outlays will be reduced, but he does not quantify them. At this stage I refer briefly, as time is short, to the statement made by the Minister in the House on 12 February 1986, in which he announced the amnesty. He stated:
. . . new moves by the Government . . . to significantly reduce social security overpayments and to further improve the administration of pensions, benefits and allowances.

There is no proof of significant reduction; there is no significant estimate. Such estimates as are given in the Minister's statement and in other statements made by Government members give no indication of the basis of their quantifications. With all the publicity given to this subject in recent months-there are estimates by the police of up to $300m being overpaid or improperly paid annually-nobody can truly quantify the actual amount. Further, the significance for the administration of pensions, benefits and allowances so far as this Act is concerned, escapes me. It may be that there are other administrative procedures which the Minister had in mind when he said that, but which are not part of this actual measure. The Minister went on in his 12 February statement to say:

Over the past three years this Government has taken a number of steps to reform the Australian social security system, and to ensure that it is more truly and more accurately needs based. These steps include moves to reduce overpayments-actions such as the transfer of some two million payments from cheques to direct deposit, and the introduction of much stricter proof of identity procedures. These and other moves are starting to prove very effective. The net level of overpayments detected by my Department last financial year fell below $20m.

I turn to the Auditor-General's report and the facts that that report reveals as to the actual efficiency and ability of the Department last year to detect overpayments. The report to which I refer is the Auditor-General's report of March 1986. Shortage of time means that I will not be able to quote at length from the section on the Department of Social Security. The relevant pages are 118 to 126. I recommend them as serious reading to anybody who has an interest in reducing fraud against the public purse to see just what the possibilities are. In the time available I shall try to highlight the areas most significant to today's debate.
In relation to pension entitlement reviews, referred to as PERs, the Auditor-General states:

The audit of invalid pensions in Victoria and the audits of other pension type systems in other regional offices revealed significant arrears Australia-wide in the conduct of these reviews . . . Instances were found where age pension records did not have an automatic review date and reviews of age pensioners' assets had not been programmed.

In regard to the arrears in PERs, State Administrations in Victoria and Western Australia advised that PERs were suspended during the introduction of the assets test in order to minimise confusion through forwarding more than one questionnaire to pensioners within a short period.

One could understand that there could have been some confusion if more than one questionnaire was forwarded, but surely this increased the chances of overpayment and should have been included as an administrative cost of the introduction of the assets test. The report further states:
Audit expressed its concern to the Department's Central Office as to the unsatisfactory national situation on reviews and sought comments as follows:
confirmation that all suspended review cases were retained in the PER system and will be actioned by early 1986
action intended to be taken on any resultant underpayments or overpayments
national policy and procedures relating to the review or field officer visit requirements for supporting parent beneficiaries, and
national policy and procedures relating to age pensioners' assets reviews.
In responding the Department has advised that:
suspended review cases would be reviewed either under a new annual review system or during 1986 and thereafter subject to existing PER procedures.
Let us understand that pension entitlement reviews experienced a significant hiatus. It continues:
upon resumption of the reviews it is proposed to adjust the rate of pension and either recover overpayments or pay arrears where necessary.

It should be pointed out that, at the time the Auditor-General was having this communication with the Department, the amnesty had not been announced. It was prior to that. Thus, prior to the announcement of an amnesty, the Department advised that it proposed to adjust the rate of pensions and either recover overpayments or pay arrears where necessary. Therefore, as a result of a government decision not to send out the review questionnaires at the same time as the one necessary for the assets test, genuine cases of inadvertence would arise-the Department was not, at the time it communicated this to the Auditor-General, proposing any sort of humanitarian action towards those overpayments. The Department's advice continued:
review of supporting parents' benefits is now undertaken in accordance with regular PER procedures and through other aspects of the Department's review mechanisms, and
the eligibility of pensioners who are subject to the assets test or who are income tested and have assessable assets within $20 000 of the threshold limit is to be reviewed annually.

I interpolate that I hope that the Department, which shows such vigour in following up on the assets test provisions for those who show themselves to be within $20,000 of the threshold limit, will show the same sort of vigour as the Auditor-General suggested it ought to be showing towards unemployment benefit recipients. The Department's sloppy approach to and co-ordination with Commonwealth Employment Service offices, its poor attempts to establish the basic information that should be on every applicant's file during the process of assessment of eligibility and the lack of attempts to pursue information available to it are all detailed in the Auditor-General's report to which I have referred.

Since time is running out, I give just one further quote which illustrates what I have been saying. In relation to an audit of overpayments-in a section headed `Overpayments' and sub-headed `Delays in recovering overpayments'-the Auditor-General reported:
The audit in Victoria found that in many cases delays in the order of five months occurred before recovery action was taken.

Audit examinations in Western Australia also disclosed that the system for following-up overpayments (the suspected overpayments system), being piloted in that State and referred to in the September 1985 report-
that is, the September 1985 Auditor-General's report-

was not operating satisfactorily. It was found that reports from the system were incomplete and inaccurate because, in many instances, suspected overpayments were not being input at the time of detection. Audit also noted coding errors, ineffective follow-up of outstanding cases (some in excess of 13 weeks), and other operating deficiencies. These results raise doubts as to whether all overpayments have been brought promptly to account and actioned in that State.

That paragraph from the Auditor-General's report is, I believe, a damning indictment of the Department. Other sections of the report refer to the effect of industrial action in increasing the risk of overpayments. There is also reference to the slackness of the Department, following industrial action, in following the procedures that it should in order to ascertain how that industrial action had affected overpayments. All this and more are in the report. Frankly, after reading the Auditor-General's report, one really has a different view on the amnesty. If there are genuine people in this position-I imagine there are some-they will be able to get off the treadmill. In the future there will be no excuse. The future measures the Minister outlined in his statement on the subject-such as letters going out every six months-are welcome. That will be costly, but it is appropriate and there will be no excuse of inadvertence from then on. However, after reviewing all the facts, the speeches and the Auditor-General's report, I have come to the conclusion that the greatest beneficiary of this amnesty is the Department of Social Security. It has an opportunity to wipe clean the slate, to have a let-out next time around from that sort of Auditor-General's report. The Department will be able to say: `That is all past tense, because we have had the amnesty. Now, of course, we will do better'. Unfortunately every Auditor-General's report gives examples of the Department saying how it is reviewing its procedures and how everything will be hunky-dory in the future. Personally, after 12 years, I have become a bit cynical. I suggest to Government members that they should not get to carried away with their enthusiasm for the amnesty. They might take a close look at the Auditor-General's report in, say, 12 or 18 months time. I think we will be reading the same story as we have prior to the amnesty; that is, sloppy administration by people who ought to take some responsibility for their lack of action and lack of professionalism in allowing the overpayments ever to happen on such a scale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those who have made a contribution to the debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill. I want to comment generally on some of the principal points that have been made, particularly by the Opposition and initially by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), who is the Opposition's spokesman in this area. Once again on an important occasion, during a debate within this Parliament on social security policy, the honourable member for Richmond has forgone his opportunity to debate the policy questions which undoubtedly underlie the legislation. Quite contrary to what the honourable member for Richmond has suggested, the Government and I are interested in developing a comprehensive and consistent overall approach to social security policy. Indeed, since I have been the Minister the major objective that I have set myself has been to ensure that there is a review of some of the central tenets of social security policy.

SPEECH.PARA: To that end, the Government has put in train a review of social security policy which will be carried out by the Department, with the assistance of Associate Professor Cass from the University of Sydney, the Social Welfare Research Centre at the University of New South Wales and a small number of additional consultants. Essentially the review will be a departmental review but it will go to some of the central aspects of social security policy-the area of family income support, which has been referred to by a number of honourable members in the chamber during this debate; the whole area of social security in the labour market, again an area on which the Opposition has some views although one would have thought that those views were somewhat ill-developed at this stage; and lastly the area of retirement incomes policy, ensuring in particular that our approach to superannuation fits well with our approach to retirement incomes. So policy is of a pre-eminent concern.

I have to say again that I am disappointed that the Opposition has consistently shown no interest in the development of social security policy. It is rare indeed that a question is asked or a speech is made either within this Parliament or outside the Parliament from which we can get any clear understanding of what the Opposition's alternative approach might be not only to economic policy but also in this case to crucial areas of social policy. That is unfortunate. It is primarily the duty of an opposition to enter into debate on government policy, and the sad thing about the current Opposition is that it is so divided internally, factionally, that it is unable to put together coherent statements on anything, let alone the difficult area of social security policy.

Having said that, I appreciate the continuing contributions made by the Opposition with regard to questions of management and administration. Certainly it is important that we have in the Parliament opportunities to make some judgments about the administration of various departments. I have noted that the honourable member for Richmond says publicly what he apparently does not say privately-that he believes that there is a problem of morale within the Department of Social Security, that there is insecurity and so on and that the Department is not, if you like, in the best of shape. I think that any large department, such as the Department of Social Security, which administers a system on the scale of the system we have in Australia clearly will have within it particular areas in which there will be problems that need to be addressed. The particular area that seems to be a continuing preoccupation of the Opposition is this area of overpayments. That is important within the context of this Bill, which, as part of an overall approach to the question of overpayments, includes the legislative provisions which provide the basis for the amnesty currently in operation.

It has been suggested that we need to have an amnesty because the Department of Social Security is not coping with the resources it has been given. It has also been suggested that we need an amnesty because we need to write off bad debts rather than provide adequate staff resources to address the problem and that the amnesty is not supported by officers in the Department of Social Security, the Australian Federal Police or by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It has been suggested that I, as Minister for Social Security, am asking for a blank cheque to write off bad debts owing to the Department of Social Security. All of those assertions were made by the honourable member for Richmond in his contribution to the debate.

Let me say that the Department of Social Security, like any other department, has to live within limited resource constraints. One of the things we all find puzzling about the Opposition is that it is led by a classical monetarist who publicly takes the most severe views about public spending, yet the Opposition is talking about additional expenditure as soon as it gets into office-whenever that may be, perhaps early in the next century-of somewhere between $6 billion and $10 billion. The honourable member for Richmond, who is a member of the National Party of Australia, has been part of what is presumably some sort of collective process that continues to imagine massive additional elements of expenditure, very few of which have any relationship at all to poverty and the greatest need. We hear all this bleating about the greatest need but when we hear about what the Opposition would do if it were in government we find that it wants to spend billions of dollars, and certainly not in the direction of reducing poverty within Australia.

Of course there are resource constraints within the Department of Social Security, and there will continue to be resource constraints because this Government is determined to ensure that in terms of staffing resources we live within our means. That is not something we make an apology for. The reduction of overpayments has been a major area of priority since I have been the Minister for Social Security. I have sought to ensure that there are adequate resources in this area and that that there are increased resources in the area of the prevention of overpayments and fraud. But let me say that there will never be unlimited resources, which is why the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) suggested that to some extent areas such as overpayments have been a problem as long as there has been a social security system. There will always be limited resources to deal with this problem, which is the current situation.

In terms of writing off bad debts, the amnesty effectively provides an opportunity, as I said in my second reading speech, for people who have failed to inform the Department of changed circumstances. By definition they are people whom the Department has limited knowledge about. By definition under the amnesty those people are encouraged to provide additional information which will enable the Department to set the record straight. Amnesties do not provide penalties or effectively they would not be amnesties. So it is not a question of writing off bad debts. It is a question of having people in the community identify themselves as people who need to provide the Department of Social Security with additional information. As a result of the amnesty we will not only achieve significant savings but also we will get a much better understanding of the circumstances in which overpayments occur, at least from a certain group of people.

It is a nonsense to suggest that in terms of overpayments the amnesty is the whole of our strategy. It is an important part of the strategy but it is only one element of it. We have also sought to improve communication, which we referred to this week, primarily because for the first time the notices are going out in plain English. The whole presentation will substantially improve progressively over the next couple of years. That is an anti-overpayment strategy or has that element as part of it. In terms of reviews, I have read the Auditor-General's report and I understand the criticisms that have been made of the Department, some of which are not without foundation and need to be addressed. I have sought to ensure that its recommendations and judgments are progressively addressed by the Department of Social Security and that we achieve a better relationship and better co-ordination between the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service. I have sought to ensure that there are increased resources and greater effort with respect, not to reviewing everyone within the social security system, but to ensuring that there are targeted reviews which are more effective in achieving a reduction in overpayments. All those problems are being addressed.

Let me make a couple of comments that I think are useful in terms of getting this matter into perspective. People who suggest that somehow in social security we are dealing with a problem of the scale of the taxation problem are talking absolute nonsense. As the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) has pointed out a number of times in this House, the real story-the official story, if you like-is that more than 90 per cent of all serious fraud investigated by the Federal Police is on the revenue side of the Budget. That is why I have referred again and again in debates such as this to the tax avoidance problem we inherited from the previous Government which was massive. I refer to the draft White Paper on `The Reform of the Australian Taxation System' of June 1985. It states:

Accordingly, accurate measurements of the amount of tax revenue forgone through evasion practice is not possible but Tax Office estimates for 1984-85 suggest that income tax evasion may involve a revenue loss of at least $3 billion per annum.

That is what one has to bear in mind when one talks about these two matters. On the one hand one is talking about a massive problem which afflicts our taxation system and which the Government is seeking to address and, on the other hand, a much more limited problem which constantly needs to be addressed and which we are seeking to do something about.

A number of honourable members, including the honourable member for Richmond, have referred from time to time to the question of dob-ins. It is suggested that we need a Noah-type campaign in relation to overpayments. I have rejected that suggestion although I have never said that the Department is not bound-as it is bound-to investigate claims that are made to it about people who are defrauding the system. In regard to unemployment benefit dob-ins, in reviews reported since July 1985 the rate was reduced and or an overpayment was raised in 26 per cent of cases. Where there had been a dob-in the rate was increased in a number of cases. The rate was untouched in more than 70 per cent of cases. I say to the honourable member for Richmond and to Opposition members that, in a sense, in the social security area we are talking for the most part about people who are on extremely low incomes. Eighty per cent of all beneficiaries of supporting parent's benefit in this country have virtually no other income above their pensions. So we are talking about very low income people.

If we create an atmosphere in the community that suggests that people ought to be dobbing in their neighbours-that is the kind of atmosphere that the honourable member for Richmond is seeking to create when he encourages dob-ins in this area-we will be setting neighbour against neighbour. We will be encouraging anyone who has something against someone else, whom they know is on social security benefits, to have that person investigated. In the vast majority of cases-more than 70 per cent of cases-the people who are subsequently investigated are receiving their correct payment, a payment to which they are entitled. So I reject the approach which has been suggested by a number of Opposition members.

Those were the principal issues raised by the Opposition. Of course I reject the Opposition's amendment as it seeks to misrepresent what the amnesty is all about. The amendment does not reflect any serious policy consideration on the part of the Opposition. Despite the amount of time-disproportionate amount of time in my view-given by the Opposition to this issue, it does not suggest that Opposition members have got their views together in respect of the administration of the Department, and particularly overpayments. The Department of Social Security, given its scale and the massive increase in the number of beneficiaries-not in our Government's time but in the last 10 years as a result of unemployment and marriage separations-has sought to address the problem. I acknowledge that there are deficiencies that need to be rectified, and we have been progressively rectifying them. In this legislation the amnesty will provide one of the ways in which we can assist in developing a comprehensive strategy on overpayments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Given the Prime Minister's recent statement that he has received commitments from the United States that it will direct subsidised products away from Australia's traditional export markets, what has the Prime Minister done and what will he do to offset these United States actions, which are contrary to his assurances given to the House this week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. He will recall that my colleague the Minister for Primary Industry has responded to the question of United States wheat sales to the Yemen and I think nothing is usefully added to that answer. It was comprehensively dealt with by the Minister. But I did note that part of the honourable member's question dealing with alleged United States rice sales to Papua New Guinea, and I will address myself to that part of his question.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is currently the sole supplier of rice to Papua New Guinea. In 1984-85 Australian exports to Papua New Guinea totalled 111,000 tonnes, valued at over $50m. That represented, as I think the honourable member will know, about one-third of the total of Australia's rice exports. The market clearly is therefore of paramount importance to the Australian rice industry and exports of possible subsidised United States sales are of extreme concern to this Government. Our Embassy in Washington was assured by United States officials on Wednesday that no subsidies for rice sales to Papua New Guinea have been requested under the export enhancement program or any other United States Government guaranteed credit program. My understanding is that Australian rice industry representatives also do not expect any sale to Papua New Guinea to involve an EEP subsidy. I acknowledge that the local industry believes that it has reliable information indicating that negotiations for United States rice sales to Papua New Guinea are well advanced, but our officials have checked with the United States Agriculture Service, the Commodity Credit Corporation and the United States Rice Council, which all claimed to be unaware of any United States sale of rice to Papua New Guinea.

United States rice prices have declined significantly in recent weeks as a result of other provisions of the 1985 Farm Act. Those provisions-particularly, as the honourable member might be aware, the marketing loan provisions-were firmly in place prior to my visit to Washington. The Administration said that, while it noted our concern for these provisions, a concern I can assure the honourable member I put most vigorously to the Administration, and the potential impact they might have on world rice prices, it was not in a position to change the provisions at this point of time. Low priced sales of United States rice on world markets cannot be ruled out. However, our officials in Washington will remain in close contact with United States officials on this matter to ensure that our concerns are kept before the United States Administration.

Given what I know to be the legitimate interests and concerns of the honourable member, if I ascertain any further information which needs to be given to add to or qualify that answer in any way, I assure him that he will receive that information at the earliest possible opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of claims that small business has been disadvantaged by Government economic and industrial policies, particularly in relation to its capacity to increase employment? Can the Minister advise the House whether there is any evidence to support these allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of these claims but, of course, they are totally lacking in evidence to support them. Such claims have been made especially by our supposed Opposition. The fact is that evidence is available from a survey of employment and earnings, conducted quarterly by the Australian Statistician, which shows that there has been very strong employment growth by small business while this Government has been in office. The latest survey was carried out for the December quarter and it shows a growth in the employment of wage and salary earners for the year to December 1985 of 4.8 per cent, which is obviously a very high rate of growth. Of that 4.8 per cent, the public sector accounted for a relatively small proportion-only about 14 per cent. The private sector accounted for 86 per cent of the growth, it having had a growth in the employment of wage and salary earners in 1985 of 6 per cent, which was a tremendously high rate of growth.

ANSWER.PARA: Not only was there strong growth in the private sector as a whole but also there was very strong growth amongst small business. One can get from the Statistician some unpublished data to complement what is in the published data. Taking the smallest of the three categories of private sector firms, which is firms with less than 20 employees, if one looks at the rate of growth of employment in that sector one finds that in the year to November 1985, the latest figures available, there was a growth in employment of 5.8 per cent, compared with growth for the private sector as a whole of 5.8 per cent. That is obviously a very high rate of growth for that small business sector. If one goes back two years, to November 1984, one finds growth for this small business sector over the period of 9.6 per cent, slightly higher than the whole private sector rate of 9.5 per cent.

Finally, one can also get other figures which relate to another definition of small business. The Bureau of Industry Economics defines small business as firms in the non-manufacturing sector with less than 20 employees and firms in the manufacturing sector with less than 100 employees. Using that definition we can see that growth in small business in the year to November 1985 was 6.3 per cent and in the two years to November 1985 it was 9.8 per cent. Clearly small business has experienced very high rates of growth, higher than for the private sector as a whole.

It follows from that that allegations that this Government has in some way instituted economic policies, taxation policies and wages policies which have inhibited the growth in employment in small business are arrant nonsense. There is no evidence whatsoever to support that. The evidence shows clearly that with the centralised wages system in operation there has been an explosion of employment in small business in this country, and obviously this Government deserves credit for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker: I ask, through you, for the Minister to table the unpublished Australian Bureau of Statistics information from which he quoted, the Bureau of Industry Economics material from which he quoted and any other unpublished material.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I ask: When will this Government of wankers living on tick--

—I do not suffer from his complaint, Madam Speaker. The history of Australia's lack of competitiveness is a sad and sorry history. It goes back some years now to when the last Government was running a current account deficit of 6 per cent of gross domestic product in 1981. That current account deficit subsided temporarily in 1982-83 only because of the massive recession which cut imports. What may have seemed to be a temporary improvement in the current account deficit in 1982-83 was only a response to the grave recession Australia was in. The fact is that the Australian economy has been uncompetitive for a long time. The massive overvaluation of the exchange rate allowed by the former Government, which I can never understand in terms of the National Party's supposed interest in rural producers, rendered Australia's exporters uncompetitive in world markets and smashed our import competing industries. That, coupled with a wages explosion in 1981 when we saw the metal union secure $39 a week--
—Bill Kelty fixed that.

The first was the Commonwealth Budget deficit and the second was the current account deficit. As the Government placed demand back in the Australian economy it started to stress the current account and suck in imports and hence exacerbated the current account.

ANSWER.PARA: The fundamental changes the Government has put into place to deal with the problem are first, the float of the dollar, which has allowed a 30 per cent-plus depreciation of the exchange rate to restore our competitiveness and secondly, a dramatic change in the performance of wage outcomes in this country which are now akin to and as good as some of the most flexible labour markets in the world. Those two factors in time will correct the fundamental imbalance we face. I would have thought that Dr Edwards, with his background in economics--

TALK.START.PARA: —He knows the reality of it.
—Order!

—I would have thought that he would have been more vocal in the last Government in recognising the fact that in not being prepared to face up to the exchange rate and trying to use it as an anti-inflation weapon, when it had no wages policy and an erratic monetary policy, its behaviour and its total gutlessness in dealing with these fundamental imbalances was the singular cause for the unbalancing of the Australian economy back towards an agrarian economy producing grains, wheat, wool, meat, minerals and not another thing.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that this Government has done the right thing in every respect in trying to correct this fundamental imbalance and in trying to shave domestic demand in the economy towards the end of last year, which the national account showed was growing at the rate of 6.7 per cent-twice the Budget forecast of 3 per cent. The Government did the right thing in tightening monetary policy to slow down that demand so as not to exacerbate the import growth problem and hence the current account. That policy has been relaxed since. Interest rates have fallen by about 4 to 5 per cent. But the fact is that it will have induced a slowing of the economy which will make it more domestically compatible with our external conditions. In the opportunities I had at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and International Monetary Fund meetings I urged upon member states, particularly Japan and Germany, that, in the face of zero inflation, they should try to lift their growth performance, if not by fiscal policy, by going on the relaxed side of monetary policy because it is only by a lift in international growth that eventually commodity prices will rise for both developed and developing countries and, given the massive increase in export volumes-

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done with oil?

—If the dummies opposite would listen for a second they might learn something. It is only by the lift in commodity prices coming off this massive growth in export volumes, which the Government's policies have induced through the exchange rate, that our current account will be easily corrected other than by requiring a different stance of policy internally. The fact is that whatever the world provides us we have to deal with. The fact is that we must deal with it as it is. That is why the Government has said consistently that as the weight of policy shifts off monetary policy the burden will shift on to fiscal policy.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for Berowra inquires of me whether we should reduce the social wage. The fact is that the social wage in that sense has been cut by the discount coming off the April case, when it is heard, of 2 per cent in the face of the 30 per cent price change on the exchange rate. In other words, we have been able to induce a cut in wages in recognition of the fact that there will be a surge of imported prices coming off the depreciation. That is why the inflationary surge is temporary, and that is why we have secured the appropriate wage adjustment in the face of the changed conditions. As this is the first serious question directed to me in months about the domestic economy and about the general cast of economic policy, I provided the honourable member with a serious reply to the fundamental problems but reminded him and the cowboys on his front bench that it was their behaviour in 1982-

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on! If you are starting that again-
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor. If he continues to disregard the Chair I will name him.
—I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. I responded to the Treasurer who was getting back to his old tricks of insult. He should cut out the bit about cowboys.
—There is no point of order. The honourable member for O'Connor will remember that I have warned him.

—The fact of the matter is-and this needs to be driven home and driven into the mind of every domestic manufacturer, every farmer, every miner-that the cause of their distress through 1982 and 1983 was the over-valuation of the exchange rate by the coalition and the destruction wrought by the metal trades round in the absence of a wages policy of the kind Opposition members now espouse again; they are not learning any lessons from their past mistakes. TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware that since World War II successive Australian governments have accepted the responsibility for burial or cremation of at least 130,000 returned servicemen and women whose lives were shortened, and that was accepted as such, as the result of the service they gave to this nation? Is the Minister aware that the new seemingly money-hungry management board of Brisbane Crematorium Ltd has now made public statements advising that at Mount Thompson Crematorium they really do intend, in the year 2007, unless a niche fee is again paid, to evict older urns, dump the ashes and re-sell the niches? In view of the fact that hundreds of former servicemen and women are at rest at Mount Thompson and the other crematorium at Albany Creek in Brisbane, and in view of the assurance of the Commonwealth Government that the remains of our war dead were laid to sacred rest in perpetuity, will the Minister act to call a gathering of the responsible State Ministers to ensure that this cold, callous, commercial approach is itself buried forever from the Australian scene?

—Yes, the Minister and the Commonwealth War Graves Commission are aware of the situation-largely as a result of the publicity given to the matter by the honourable member for Moreton. The matter is not merely of concern to the War Graves Commission; the Minister for Veterans' Affairs assures me that his Department is moving on the matter. He has indicated that it is a matter of the deepest concern, and he has been very carefully monitoring the situation overseas. We have had to make it clear that we regard the war graves of Australian dead in some parts of the Middle East as sacrosanct. —Will the Minister for the Arts, Heritage and Environment outline to the House and the Australian people what action has been taken by the Federal Government relating to the grounding of the Jhansi Ki Rani on the Frederick Reef 300 kilometres east of Mackay? Can he assure the people of Australia that there will be no damage flowing from the grounding of that vessel?

—The honourable member is correct in saying that the ship did strike Frederick Reef about 300 nautical miles off Mackay, at about 6 o'clock on Thursday, 24 April. The ship was carrying some 74,000 tonnes of coal and approximately 870 tonnes of oil. It is grounded and it is taking water. Salvage is being assessed, but the risk of either a cargo or fuel spill appears now to be very low. If a spill occurs the threat to the Great Barrier Reef is still considered to be low. It is of course outside the area of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park by some miles. So, when I am talking about this legislation, I am talking about the national companies and securities legislation which has been before the Parliament. It is a set piece of legislation which is amended from time to time. Mr McCrann failed to understand my complaint that under the existing legislation; that is, the same legislation, the small shareholder was not having an opportunity to take up an offer if there was too much litigation, depending on the interpretation of the legislation. I think Mr McCrann failed to understand that. I propose to write a letter to Mr McCrann. I hope he prints it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—I do, Madam Speaker. In the course of Question Time, when answering a question from the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) repeated, by reference to imputed exchange rate policies that I followed whilst I was Treasurer, the totally erroneous proposition that Australia'a current account deficit problems were generated during the years the Fraser Government was in office. That is wrong. It is one of the great pieces of mythology that this Government is trying to develop.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Government members guffaw, stand and protest. I will tell them where it is wrong, and that is the basis of my personal explanation. The average current account deficit for the Fraser years was 3.7 per cent of gross domestic product and for each of the three years the present Treasurer has been in office it has been massively above that figure.
—On the same point of order, Madam Speaker: I am very careful about what I say. What I said I will repeat.
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: May I inquire what this is?
—Order! The Treasurer has sought the call to make a personal explanation, I gather.

—Yes. I claim to have been misrepresented by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). Let me repeat explicitly what I said. In 1981-82 the current account deficit of this country was 6 per cent of the gross domestic product. That is a matter of fact. It is in the Budget Papers. It went on in that mode and only repaired itself temporarily in the recession of 1982-83. In other words, the deterioration in Australia's external accounts and trading position cannot be reflected in some average of the so-called Fraser years but in the situation in the middle of the Fraser years. The Fraser Government let wages explode in 1981 as a cause of that and as a cause of the over-valuation of the exchange rate.

—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: This is all very interesting and very enlightening but it is not a matter for the exchange of comment; it is a matter for personal explanation, and this is not one.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat and the Treasurer will wind up.

—I claim to have been further misrepresented by the fact that the Leader of the Opposition alleges that the figure he gave is a reflection of the conditions which prevailed; it is not. The conditions which prevailed were a consequence of, firstly, his exchange rate policy and, secondly, his wages explosion. Therefore, I was absolutely dead right in everything I said.

—Madam Speaker, this is an important matter of public policy, and I seek leave to speak further to my personal explanation. I am simply not prepared to allow the Treasurer to get away with this continued myth that he postulates.

—Order! The Chair will now explain to the House that personal explanations are made with the indulgence of the Chair and they should be personal explanations. Honourable members must show the House where they personally have been misrepresented. The Leader of the Opposition and the Treasurer in my opinion are taking part in a debate in which one is refuting a point made by the other. The Chair is not prepared to allow any further indulgence.
—Madam Speaker, with great respect, I am sorry but I am simply not prepared to allow this. I have a right as a member of this House to seek your indulgence.
—Order! The Chair is not giving indulgence for any further debate.
—Madam Speaker, are you saying that you are not prepared to give me the customary indulgence as Leader of the Opposition to correct a misrepresentation?

—I am saying that I have given indulgence to the Leader of the Opposition and I have given indulgence to the Treasurer. As far as I am concerned we are going to get into a total debating situation where each rebuts the other.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Uren, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will replace the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 and provide for continuation of a Commonwealth program of general purpose financial assistance for local government in the States and the Northern Territory. I explained on 10 April that the Government, following consultation with the States and local government, had accepted the overall finding of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance that the Commonwealth should maintain a program of general purpose support for local government but that the character of the program should be changed in certain respects. This Bill gives effect to those changes which are necessary to bring about a gradual improvement in the effectiveness and equity of the program.

I am particularly pleased to be able to introduce this legislation, which consolidates past achievements and lays the foundation for future progress. As a Minister in the Whitlam Government I was associated with the development of the first Bill which provided for Commonwealth financial assistance for local government. The Grants Commission Act 1973 was an historic breakthrough in inter-government financial relations. It created the precedent for direct Commonwealth involvement in the field of local government. To the credit of the Fraser Government, our initiative in 1973 was built upon and improved through the introduction in 1976 of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act. The main improvements related to the provision of funds for every council and the introduction of a system for allocation of funds by local government grants commissions in each State. This Bill introduces some changes designed to bring stability, clarity and accountability to the allocation of untied grants to local councils. Fundamentally, it represents continuation of a bipartisan commitment to the development of local government.

The Hawke Government is active across a number of fronts in strengthening local government capabilities and in forstering co-operative inter-government relations. We recognise the important contribution that the local government makes in its own right and through its involvement in Commonwealth-sponsored programs to social and economic development. We value the diversity, decentralisation and responsiveness of local government. We understand how local government has been evolving as a sophisticated, multi-functional level of community government in Australia. In this regard, we have sought the participation of local government on the Economic Planning Advisory Council. We have upgraded the Office of Local Government for the purpose of strengthening links and improving information exchange among the three spheres of government. We have participated actively through the Local Government Ministers Conference on inter-governmental task forces concerned with the role of local government in economic development and in community development. We have sponsored over the last three years through the local government development program some 400 projects designed to spread the best ideas and practices throughout the local government system. We have launched a series of national awards for innovations in local government and we have pursued the constitutional recognition of local government.

These various initiatives come together for the mutual benefit of the Commonwealth, the States and local government. For all concerned, past barriers to communication and consultation are breaking down. Co-operation and trust is building up. From the Commonwealth perspective, and in the light of the fact that Federal Government expenditure flowing to local government exceeds $1 billion, the improving relations allow us to achieve more cost effective returns for the nation's investment in the local government system. Over half of that Commonwealth contribution to local government is in the form of untied grants. This Bill provides for continuity and growth in the provision of these grants but in so doing it establishes a new basis for the provision of funds.

Under the Act that is being replaced, the grants for local government were tied to a percentage of personal income tax receipts. This formula led to great variations in funding from year to year and created difficulties in local government's relationship with the States. No such linkage will be provided in the new Act. Instead the Bill provides for a base level of funding that is equivalent to the level of funding received by local government in the States and the Northern Territory in 1985-86 plus an adjustment to bring Northern Territory per capita payments into line with those in the States. This provides a base figure of $540.9m. The Bill provides that the actual payment for local government in 1986-87 shall be this base figure multiplied by either the increase in the consumer price index for that year or by the percentage change in Commonwealth general purpose payments to the States, whichever is the greater. The payment calculations for 1987-88 shall be the same as those for 1986-87. For all subsequent years payment calculations will be based simply on the percentage change in Commonwealth general purpose payments to the States. That is, local government will be treated no less favourably than the States in terms of periodic adjustments to the funding level of the program. These new financial arrangements will provide a stable financial base from which local government will be able to plan with a greater degree of certainty than under the previous arrangement. The volatility that characterised the previous tax sharing arrangements will be eliminated.

As under the previous Act, the Bill provides for the payments for local government to be made to each State in one lump sum early in the financial year. If the estimates on which the grants are made turn out to be incorrect there is provision for a subsequent adjustment to be made to the grant. This would normally occur through an adjustment to the following year's grant. Such an adjustment might be necessary if, for instance, the rate of inflation turns out to be lower than anticipated. Each State's share of the total grant will, from 1989-90 onwards, be equal to that State's share of the Australian population. In the two years before then, the shares of each State will be gradually changed from the present relativities to a population basis. As a result of these changes Victoria and South Australia will increase their share of the grants. The other States will reduce their share but in such a way that there will be no reduction in the payment to any of these States in money terms from one year to the next.

The principal objective of this program is to provide financial assistance to those local councils who are most disadvantaged with respect to their ability to raise revenue and to provide services. In attaining this objective, the States will be required to allocate funds in such a way as to equalise each local council's ability to undertake its functions with respect to the average standard performance of other local councils in the State concerned. At the same time the Government recognises that local government, as a whole, has a restricted base from which to raise revenue to finance its expanding functions. Because of this the Government has ensured that every council continues to receive benefits under the program. The legislation provides that the grant received by any council will be at least the amount it would have been entitled to if 30 per cent of the funds available to each State had been distributed among local councils on a straight per capita basis.

In each State a Local Government Grants Commission will continue to be responsible for determining the allocation of funds among local councils. A new requirement is that eventually each Grants Commission must have at least two members who are, or have been, associated with local government in that State. The Bill requires that these Grants Commissions hold public hearings and that at least once every three years they publish a report setting out details of the methods they use in recommending allocations among local councils. The Grants Commissions are also required to observe principles that are established under the Act for the purpose of allocating amounts among local councils.

It is recognised that these principles will take some time to develop and to put into effect. Consequently the Bill allows five years for the introduction of such principles. In the meantime Grants Commissions are required to observe the methods of allocating amounts used under the preceding Act or, alternatively, any agreement that has been reached between the responsible State Minister and the Commonwealth Minister. The development of principles for the purpose of allocating funds between local councils is designed to bring an element of uniformity between States without requiring that every State adopt exactly the same principles. It is intended that these principles will be drawn up by each State in accordance with the purposes of the legislation and submitted to me as the responsible Commonwealth Minister for approval. This submission is required by 1 July 1987. In the event that a State refuses to draw up principles or draws up principles which do not accord with the purposes of the Act, there is a fallback power of the Commonwealth Minister to determine the principles for that State. The Bill provides for the varying, revoking and reviewing and of the principles. The review mechanisms will enable the principles to be kept fully up to date with improvements in the practices of the Grants Commissions and with their understandings of the results of their distributions.

A State will not be entitled to a payment in any one year unless the responsible Commonwealth Minister, is satisfied that allocations of funds have been made in accordance with approved principles or in accordance with the alternative arrangements outlined above. The new Act will result in a redistribution of funds provided under this program to the more needy councils. This is one of its prime objectives. The Government however is concerned to ensure that changes are made gradually-I stress that-so that councils will have time to adjust to the new arrangements. It is for this reason that the Bill provides for up to five years for changes to occur in the equalisation arrangements and in the method of calculating per capita entitlements. It is for this reason also that the changes in State shares of grants are to be phased in.

The Bill is different from its predecessor in that it provides for an important role for local government itself to participate in establishing the principles which will govern the allocation of funds between local councils. It also provides for local government to be represented in any review of the Act that the Minister may require after 30 June 1992. This Bill provides important advances on the arrangements that were introduced under the Whitlam Government and improved upon by the Fraser Government. It will provide continuity and certainty for an important element of local government finance while at the same time providing for a more equitable distribution of funds than has previously occurred.

Before I commend the Bill to the House might I say how proud I am to be associated with it. I said earlier that I was the Minister in the Whitlam Government who was associated with the development of the first Bill which gave untied Federal funds to local government. In our first year, the financial year 1974-75, we made $56m available. This year, local government will receive at least $577m in untied funds-over $1 billion in tied and untied funds-which is more than a 50 per cent increase on funds allocated in the last year of the Fraser Government. When I retire as a Minister of the Hawke Government at the end of this Parliament, whether it be in late 1987 or in early 1988, I will have spent eight years as the Minister responsible for local Government. During those years from the early 1970s, local government has evolved from authorities dealing with roads, gutters, drains and garbage to increasingly sophisticated multi-factional and multi-functional authorities dealing with human and community services. That evolvement is a healthy process because local government is nearest to the people. It is my belief that people should have a greater say over the governing of their lives. I have been an anti-centralist all my political life so it gives me great pride to see the evolutionary process of local government and I think it is a healthy aspect in our democratic process to see it emerging. May this Bill encourage that continuity of development. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
